prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

prop.head.headtext: Effect of Transfer: Proceedings in the Transferee Court

head.headtext: Management of transferred cases—Motion practice in complex litigation

para.paratext: The transferee court in multidistrict litigation can hear a wide variety of pretrial motions. Any motion that could be heard in a transferor court can be heard by the transferee court while the actions are pending for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings.

The Panel has specifically identified certain motions that can be heard by the transferee court. This list is not exhaustive, but represents the motions that parties have urged should prevent the Panel from ordering transfer. The Panel has nearly uniformly declined to refuse transfer for this reason,[1] and has ordered the cases transferred for coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings and has specifically stated the motions should be heard by the transferee court. The transferee court also clearly has the power to review all matters normally considered prior to trial.[5]

Transferee judges can consider motions for their recusal, although these must avoid any odor of judge-shopping and, given the Panel's determination that a particular judge should preside over the pretrial proceedings, there is a particularly high hurdle to leap to have the transferee judge decide to have a different judge hear the case.[6]

In addition to having virtually plenary authority over motions that may be brought, a transferee court has significant power to manage and control how and when motions are presented. In one case, the court held that a defendant was not entitled to file a summary judgment motion at any time it chose and without the court's permission.[7] It noted that the court had authority to adopt special procedures to manage litigation through summary judgment, including limiting the timing of summary adjudication. These limits can supersede those that would otherwise exist under rule governing motions for summary judgment.

Another inherent power of the transferee court is the inherent power it has over the attorneys appearing before it. Attorneys appearing in the transferee court proceedings may, for example, be subject to the transferee court's jurisdiction to resolve disputes over the assessment of contributions to a common benefit fund from case settlements, including cases settled outside the MDL proceedings.[8]
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
The effect of pendency of motions in the transferor court on the transfer decision is discussed in §§ 5:40 and 5:54.

See In re Data General Corp. Antitrust Litigation, 510 F. Supp. 1220, 1226 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Oil Spill by “Amoco Cadiz” Off Coast of France on March 16, 1978, 471 F. Supp. 473, 478 (J.P.M.L. 1979); In re Commonwealth Oil/Tesoro Petroleum Securities Litigation, 458 F. Supp. 225 (J.P.M.L. 1978); In re Midwest Milk Monopolization Litigation, 398 F. Supp. 676, 678 (J.P.M.L. 1975).

See, e.g., In re Plumbing Fixture Cases, 298 F. Supp. 484 (J.P.M.L. 1968). The handling of class action matters in the transferee court is discussed in greater detail in John T. McDermott, The Transferee Judge—The Unsung Hero of Multidistrict Litigation, 35 Mont. L. Rev. 15, 19–29 (1974). See also In re Bisphenol-A (BPA) Polycarbonate Plastic Products Liability Litigation, 276 F.R.D. 336, 339 (W.D. Mo. 2011) (transferee court holds it has authority to decide class certification in single-state class action); In re Conagra Peanut Butter Products Liability Litigation, 251 F.R.D. 689 (N.D. Ga. 2008) (transferee court decision dealing with class certification in MDL docket).
See In re Royal Ahold N.V. Securities and ERISA Litigation, 219 F.R.D. 343 (D. Md. 2003).

See, e.g., Sentner v. Amtrak, 540 F. Supp. 557 (D.N.J. 1982) (amendment of pleadings in transferred cases); Humphreys v. Tann, 487 F.2d 666 (6th Cir. 1973), cert. denied, 416 U.S. 956, 94 S. Ct. 1970, 40 L. Ed. 2d 307 (1974) (transferee court can hear summary judgment motion); Kaiser Industries Corp. v. Wheeling-Pittsburgh Steel Corp., 328 F. Supp. 365 (D. Del. 1971). Transferee courts also may consider motions in limine to exclude prejudicial evidence, including holding Daubert hearings as to expert witnesses. See, e.g., Rowland v. Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corp., 9 F. Supp. 3d 553 (W.D. Pa. 2014). Other evidentiary issues, especially those pertaining to individual cases, are typically left to be decided by the trial judge following remand. For a general discussion of the limits of pretrial procedures, see Roger S. Haydock, David F. Herr & Jeffrey W. Stempel, Fundamentals of Pretrial Litigation (10th ed. 2016).

See, e.g., In re African-American Slave Descendants Litigation, 307 F. Supp. 2d 977 (N.D. Ill. 2004) (motion to recuse transferee judge denied; motion based in part on testimony from the confirmation process on judge's views on the sources of law and role of judges).
In re New Motor Vehicles Canadian Export Antitrust Litigation, 229 F.R.D. 35 (D. Me. 2005). citing Manual of Complex Litigation Fourth § 11.32 (2004).

See Downing v. Goldman Phipps, PLLC, 764 F.3d 906 (8th Cir. 2014), cert. denied, 135 S. Ct. 1464, 191 L. Ed. 2d 370 (2015). For a decision on litigation by class counsel seeking to recover for the use of work product from the same MDL proceeding, see Downing v. Riceland Foods, Inc., 2015 WL 1299229 (E.D. Mo. 2015), leave to appeal denied, (8th Circ. 15-8004) (May 8, 2015). Following the Eighth Circuit's ruling in Goldman Phipps, the district court certified a large class of claimants seeking payment from those attorneys failing or refusing to make payments. See Downing v. Goldman Phipps PLLC, 2015 WL 4255342 (E.D. Mo. 2015).
